column32:
I lived 9 years with my Mac ðŸ’» Book pro 17â€œ, 2nd last generation. I had to buy a new machine for job reasons (home office). Iâ€˜ve bought a 24 iMac ðŸ–¥ with the M1.

I donâ€™t know if I will buy a â€žlaptopâ€œ. Maybe when the next job requires BYOD.

For surfing on the internet iPad pro 12.9 is excellent.

What disturbs me is that 32 bit games do not work anymore. Windows is much better considering that.

There must be a (commercial) product or a compatibility layer to run older software. If the 2 trillion company Apple doesnâ€™t want to do it, then somebody else should do it.

Pitty is that Parallels Desktop and VMware Fusion donâ€˜t want to execute x64 code. (It CANâ€™T be that difficult to implement it.)I know that Windows 10 ARM tries to run older games. But AFAIK PD and VF can run virtual Macs. I need a Mac solution.
column36:
Give 'em a break ... Delta variant.

The 2020 M1 models were mostly done in 2019 and featured minor case differences - the M1x models have new cases, new ports, and a hard to make mini-LED panel.

I think ethernet on the power adaptor would be a terrible idea ... having to haul around a power brick to get ethernet makes it a much less portable computer. Now you can't just carry it like a book, now you need a container like a backpack or carry case to bring it with you.

Also ... the MagSafe connecter for a MacBook Pro would not be as large as the MagSafe connector for an iMac - it would have to be much slimmer to fit in the MacBook's bottom case, and would have less room for conductors.

column2: I suspect the demand for pro-level hardware updates won't be there until their are pro-level updates for the apps such people use. Adobe is being particularly laggardly.
column3: If I'm completely honest, then the 2022 release for the PRO line, like the upcoming iMac with 27+ inch display, is not that inconvenient for me. Then I can build up even more reserves and buy a really good machine at the end of next year, which will then last for at least 7 years and I can get out of this half-yearly update spiral.
column4: Itâ€™s not new CPUs, so itâ€™s more them showing the existing base they arenâ€™t being abandoned. There may even be upgrades available after the transition
column5: As much as we all dislike the touch-bar, I have found myself using it quite a bit since working from home in lockdown. Its been super useful navigating PowerPoint slides when presenting over a Zoom meeting. Being able to see all my slides and skip forward or back with the touch of a finger makes it much more seamless. Im starting love when its death is on the way ðŸ˜ž
column6: I would like to know how all that GPU power translates into real-life performance in visual fx and 3d animation.

column9: We build all these expectations then disappoint ourselves.
column10: I know this is getting way ahead of things, but I know this day is coming, the day when Apple releases the larger iMac (maybe 30"?) w/Apple silicon.  And then we have to decide, forecast, guess, are we getting an iMac Pro in addition to the larger iMac soon thereafter?  Unless the larger iMac is called iMac Pro and has the silicon chips or chops to prove it; then we know we're getting the best iMac for some time.  But if it's just called the 30" iMac, my goodness, what a choice between buy or wait for an iMac Pro that may never come that will be.  Great video, Rene.  Have a great night my friend.
column11: Was waiting for M1X MBP 14" but for some reason im more curious about M2 Macbook Air. Could end up being a awesome deal in price/performance should it also get a reasonable jump in performance as Apple Silicon always has

column14: Noooo i dont want to lose the Touch Bar! But i also want a better battery and less hot ness on my current 16â€™. Choices choices
column15: When pundits first starting asking us to wait for M1X, back in December 2020, I thought that was ridiculous advice. And now you're telling us about M2, M2X, M3 and M3X. I'm not even convinced that the M series chips will upgrade as often as the A series chips.
